title: Understanding Penalties
subtitle: Yellow Flags, Yardage, and Why Rules Matter

What you'll learn: What yellow flags mean and why they're thrown
Common penalties and their yardage costs
How penalties can change game momentum

script.hook: See that yellow flag flying? Someone broke a rule. Let's decode what penalties mean and why they're game-changers.

sections.title: The Yellow Flag System
sections.content: When a referee sees a rule violation, they throw a yellow flag. The play usually continues, then refs huddle to decide the penalty. It's like getting a ticket - you broke a rule, now there's a consequence.

sections.title: Common 5-Yard Penalties
sections.content: False start - offense moves before the snap. Offside - defense crosses the line early. Delay of game - taking too long to start a play. These are minor violations that cost 5 yards.
sections.onScreen: split screen: false start, offside, delay of game animations

sections.title: Major 10-15 Yard Penalties
sections.content: Holding - illegally grabbing a player, costs 10 yards. Unnecessary roughness - hitting too hard or late, 15 yards. Pass interference can be huge - the ball moves to where the foul happened.
sections.onScreen: holding grip + roughness hit + interference examples

sections.title: Accept or Decline
sections.content: Here's the twist - the team that didn't commit the penalty can decline it. If you gained 20 yards but the defense was offside for 5, you'd decline and keep your 20-yard gain. It's strategic choice.
sections.onScreen: decision tree: 'Accept penalty' vs 'Decline and keep play result'

sections.title: Automatic First Downs
sections.content: Some defensive penalties don't just add yards - they give automatic first downs. Defensive holding, pass interference, roughing the passer. These keep drives alive even on 3rd & long.

sections.title: Quick Recap
sections.content: Yellow flag means penalty. Minor fouls cost 5 yards, major ones 10-15 or more. Teams can decline penalties, and some give automatic first downs. Penalties change games!

quiz.question: The offense gains 8 yards on a play, but the defense committed a 5-yard offside penalty. What should the offense do?
options: Accept the penalty and replay the down with 5 extra yards
Decline the penalty and keep the 8-yard gain
Both penalties offset, replay the down
The play doesn't count at all
quiz.explanation: Smart choice! Since the offense gained 8 yards (more than the 5-yard penalty would give), they should decline the penalty and keep their bigger gain.
quiz.encouragement: You understand penalty strategy! Knowing when to accept or decline is crucial.

keyTerms.definition: A rule violation that results in yardage loss or gain depending on who committed it
When an offensive player moves before the ball is snapped (5-yard penalty)
Illegally grabbing or restraining an opponent (10-yard penalty)
Illegally preventing a receiver from catching the ball (spot foul or 15 yards)
